title: Elbie Nickel
text:
Elbert Everett "Elbie" Nickel (December 28, 1922 – February 27, 2007) was a professional <a href="American%20football">American football</a> <a href="tight%20end">tight end</a> in the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a>. He played 11 seasons for the <a href="Pittsburgh%20Steelers">Pittsburgh Steelers</a> (1947–1957).
Nickel starred in three sports at the <a href="University%20of%20Cincinnati">University of Cincinnati</a> – he was an <a href="End%20%28American%20football%29">end</a> on the <a href="college%20football">football</a> team, a top scorer on the <a href="basketball">basketball</a> team and a <a href="pitcher">pitcher</a>-<a href="outfielder">outfielder</a> in <a href="baseball">baseball</a>. His education was put on hold by <a href="United%20States%20Army">Army</a> service in <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.
Generally considered one of the best tight ends in Steelers' history, Nickel recorded 329 career receptions as a tight end and is now second in career receptions by a Steelers' tight end behind Heath Miller (490). In conjunction with the 2007 celebration of the 75th anniversary of the Steelers, Nickel was selected as one of 33 players on the <a href="Pittsburgh%20Steelers%20All-Time%20Team">Pittsburgh Steelers All-Time Team</a>.
